results.title: Mao's China
results.creator_credit: Jessie Nishihata, Joe Schlesinger and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Chairman Mao’s thoughts provide the basis for a generalized explanation of Chinese society. Using Peking, Shanghai and Tientsin as examples, shows street scenes, a housing estate and a commune. Stresses the value of manual labour and the control of society by the people. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Bubbles Co-op: secondary fiction (Episode 3)
results.brief_description: This films presents two fiction films from the University of Melbourne “Bubbles Co-op” Film Festival. ine is in black and white and is technically poor; the second is shorter in length and is in colour. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary level students. No other credits available.

results.title: Bubbles Co-op: secondary animation (Episode 1)
results.brief_description: This film presents secondary school students’ animated films which were screened at the University of Melbourne “Bubbles Co-op” Film Festival. Indicates the range and depth of their concerns, imagination and considerable talents. A stimulating, amusing and refreshing compilation. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary level students. No other credits available.

results.title: Bubbles Co-op. Part 1: primary films
results.brief_description: A compilation of primary school children’s films which were screened at Melbourne University “Bubbles Co-op” Film Festival. Films shown include a science fiction drama, a social documentary and several animated films. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary level students. No other credits available.

results.title: Cricket: Australian style
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A documentary on cricket as it is played in Australia in 1974. Offers highlights from a match between Australia and New Zealand and presents comments about the game by the then Australian captain Ian Chappell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neil Howe, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Poetry for fun: dares and dreams
results.creator_credit: CEF-Central Educational Films and Centron Productions
results.brief_description: Introduces children to poetry. Presents six poems illustrated by cartoon animation and live action photography. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Bakery beat
results.brief_description: Gives a step-by-step account of the making of bread, using many close-ups and showing the comparison between a small two man bakery and a large automated one. This film is non-narrated with a music soundtrack and is applicable to themes of interdependence and social organization. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Owl and the pussycat
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A film of Barbara Cooney’s illustrations to Edward Lear’s poem. The owl and the pussycat travel in a pea-green boat to the land of Bong-tree where they are married by the turkey who lives on the hill. Photographed by Alexander Cochran. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: The Dolmetsch Story. Part 3. Making music
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Fanelodge Productions
results.brief_description: Final part in a three part series. This film is devoted to the music played and recorded in the Dolmetsch family and also in their museum. It captures the authentic sound of various instruments, which include violas, recorders, harpsicords, virginals, octavinas, spinets and fortepianos. Suitable for secondary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Fanelodge Productions

results.title: The Dolmetsch story. Part 2. Viols and fortepiano
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Fanelodge Productions
results.brief_description: Part two of a three part series. Dr Carl Dolmetsch describes the history of the viola da gamba and demonstrates how it is played. Shows its construction in the Dolmetsch workshops, along with some priceless instruments in their museum. The fortepiano is described and demonstrated and we see a recital by the Dolmetschs and Joseph Saxby. Suitable for secondary school level.
